explanation: 1) mhd_assert: This is used at the top of buffer_append and is a macro — its expansion could contain statements (including for loops). To decide whether buffer_append (as compiled/expanded) includes or introduces any for loops or violates the MISRA for-loop well-formedness rules we must inspect the mhd_assert definition and expansion. 2) memcpy: Called inside buffer_append; memcpy might be a function or a macro/inline implementation. If it is a macro or inlined implementation it could expand into code containing for loops inside buffer_append. To be sure buffer_append itself contains no problematic for loops (or contains only well-formed ones) we must see the actual declaration/implementation used in the build.
